message_1: Given the elliptic curve y² = x³ - 3x + 5 over a field with modulus 23, find the result of adding the points (6,10) and (20,7) using elliptic curve addition.
message_2:
To add two points P = (x1, y1) and Q = (x2, y2) on an elliptic curve, we need to find the slope λ and then use it to find the coordinates of the resulting point R = (x3, y3).

If P ≠ Q, the slope λ is given by:
λ = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1)

Since we are working in a field with modulus 23, we need to perform all calculations modulo 23. In this case, P = (6, 10) and Q = (20, 7), so:

λ = (7 - 10) / (20 - 6) ≡ (-3) / (14) ≡ 20 / 14 (mod 23)

Now we need to find the multiplicative inverse of 14 modulo 23. Using the extended Euclidean algorithm, we find that the inverse of 14 modulo 23 is 10. So:

λ = 20 * 10 ≡ 200 ≡ 8 (mod 23)

Now we can find the coordinates of the resulting point R:

x3 = λ² - x1 - x2 ≡ 8² - 6 - 20 ≡ 64 - 6 - 20 ≡ 38 ≡ 15 (mod 23)
y3 = λ(x1 - x3) - y1 ≡ 8(6 - 15) - 10 ≡ 8(-9) - 10 ≡ (-72) - 10 ≡ 9 (mod 23)

So, the result of adding the points (6, 10) and (20, 7) on the given elliptic curve is R = (15, 9).
